chunks.html_content: Flexible working is a way of working that suits an employee’s needs, for example having flexible start and finish times, or working from home.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
Flexible working is a way of working that suits an employee’s needs, for example having flexible start and finish times, or working from home.

chunks.html_content: Flexible working rules are different in Northern Ireland.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
Flexible working rules are different in Northern Ireland.

chunks.html_content:
All employees have the legal right to request flexible working. Employees can request a change to:

  • the number of hours they work
  • when they start or finish work
  • the days they work
  • where they work

This is known as ‘making a statutory application’.

Employees must have worked for the same employer for at least 26 weeks to be eligible.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
All employees have the legal right to request flexible working. Employees can request a change to:

  the number of hours they work
  when they start or finish work
  the days they work
  where they work

This is known as ‘making a statutory application’.
Employees must have worked for the same employer for at least 26 weeks to be eligible.

chunks.html_content: From 6 April 2024, employees will be able to request flexible working from their first day in a new job.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
From 6 April 2024, employees will be able to request flexible working from their first day in a new job.

chunks.html_content:
Employers must deal with requests in a ‘reasonable manner’.

Examples of handling requests in a reasonable manner include:

  • assessing the advantages and disadvantages of the application
  • holding a meeting to discuss the request with the employee
  • offering an appeal process

Read the Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service (Acas) code of practice on flexible working requests.

If an employer does not handle a request in a reasonable manner, the employee can take them to an employment tribunal.

An employer can refuse an application if they have a good business reason for doing so.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
What employers must do
Employers must deal with requests in a ‘reasonable manner’.
Examples of handling requests in a reasonable manner include:

  assessing the advantages and disadvantages of the application
  holding a meeting to discuss the request with the employee
  offering an appeal process

Read the Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service (Acas) code of practice on flexible working requests.
If an employer does not handle a request in a reasonable manner, the employee can take them to an employment tribunal.
An employer can refuse an application if they have a good business reason for doing so.

chunks.html_content:
There are different ways of working flexibly.

Two people do one job and split the hours.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
Job sharing
There are different ways of working flexibly.
Two people do one job and split the hours.

heading_context: Remote working and working from home
chunks.html_content: Working from anywhere other than the employee’s usual workplace. It can include working from home.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
Remote working and working from home
Working from anywhere other than the employee’s usual workplace. It can include working from home.

chunks.html_content: A combination of working remotely and working in the employee’s usual workplace.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
Hybrid working
A combination of working remotely and working in the employee’s usual workplace.

chunks.html_content: Working less than full-time hours (usually by working fewer days).
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
Part time
Working less than full-time hours (usually by working fewer days).

chunks.html_content: Working full-time hours but over fewer days - for example a 9-day fortnight.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
Compressed hours
Working full-time hours but over fewer days - for example a 9-day fortnight.

chunks.html_content: The employee chooses when to start and end work (within agreed limits) but works certain ‘core hours’, for example 10am to 4pm every day.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
Flexitime
The employee chooses when to start and end work (within agreed limits) but works certain ‘core hours’, for example 10am to 4pm every day.

chunks.html_content: The employee has to work a certain number of hours over the year but they have some flexibility about when they work. There are sometimes ‘core hours’ which the employee regularly works each week, and they work the rest of their hours flexibly or when there’s extra demand at work.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
Annualised hours
The employee has to work a certain number of hours over the year but they have some flexibility about when they work. There are sometimes ‘core hours’ which the employee regularly works each week, and they work the rest of their hours flexibly or when there’s extra demand at work.

chunks.html_content: The employee has different start, finish and break times from other workers.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
Staggered hours
The employee has different start, finish and break times from other workers.

chunks.html_content: Default retirement age has been phased out and older workers can choose when they want to retire. This means they can reduce their hours and work part time.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
Phased retirement
Default retirement age has been phased out and older workers can choose when they want to retire. This means they can reduce their hours and work part time.

chunks.html_content: Employees can apply for flexible working if they’ve worked continuously for the same employer for the last 26 weeks. It’s known as ‘making a statutory application.’
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
Employees can apply for flexible working if they’ve worked continuously for the same employer for the last 26 weeks. It’s known as ‘making a statutory application.’

chunks.html_content: From 6 April 2024, employees will be able to request flexible working from their first day in a new job.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
From 6 April 2024, employees will be able to request flexible working from their first day in a new job.

chunks.html_content:
The basic steps are:

  1. The employee writes to the employer.

  2. The employer considers the request and makes a decision within 3 months - or longer if agreed with the employee.

  3. If the employer agrees to the request, they must change the terms and conditions in the employee’s contract.

  4. If the employer disagrees, they must write to the employee giving the business reasons for the refusal. The employee may be able to complain to an employment tribunal.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
The basic steps are:


The employee writes to the employer.


The employer considers the request and makes a decision within 3 months - or longer if agreed with the employee.


If the employer agrees to the request, they must change the terms and conditions in the employee’s contract.


If the employer disagrees, they must write to the employee giving the business reasons for the refusal.  The employee may be able to complain to an employment tribunal.

chunks.html_content: From 6 April 2024, employers will need to make a decision within 2 months of getting the request.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
From 6 April 2024, employers will need to make a decision within 2 months of getting the request.

chunks.html_content: Employees can only make one application for flexible working in any 12-month period.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
Employees can only make one application for flexible working in any 12-month period.

chunks.html_content: From 6 April 2024, employees will be able to make 2 applications for flexible working in any 12-month period.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
From 6 April 2024, employees will be able to make 2 applications for flexible working in any 12-month period.

heading_context: What the email or letter must include
chunks.html_content:
An employee should email or write a letter to their employer.

Employers may ask employees to use a standard form to make an application.

The application must include:

  • the date
  • a statement that this is a statutory request
  • details of how the employee wants to work flexibly and when they want to start
  • an explanation of how they think flexible working might affect the business and how this could be dealt with, for example if they’re not at work on certain days
  • a statement saying if and when they’ve made a previous application
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
Writing to the employer
What the email or letter must include
An employee should email or write a letter to their employer.
Employers may ask employees to use a standard form to make an application.
The application must include:

  the date
  a statement that this is a statutory request
  details of how the employee wants to work flexibly and when they want to start
  an explanation of how they think flexible working might affect the business and how this could be dealt with, for example if they’re not at work on certain days
  a statement saying if and when they’ve made a previous application

chunks.html_content:
Employees should tell their employer in writing if they want to withdraw their application.

The employer can treat an application as withdrawn if the employee misses 2 meetings to discuss an application or appeal without good reason, for example sickness.

The employer must tell the employee they are treating the request as withdrawn.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
Withdrawing an application
Employees should tell their employer in writing if they want to withdraw their application.
The employer can treat an application as withdrawn if the employee misses 2 meetings to discuss an application or appeal without good reason, for example sickness.
The employer must tell the employee they are treating the request as withdrawn.

chunks.html_content:
Employers must consider flexible working requests in a ‘reasonable manner’.

They should usually make a decision within 3 months of the request (or longer if agreed with the employee).
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
Employers must consider flexible working requests in a ‘reasonable manner’.
They should usually make a decision within 3 months of the request (or longer if agreed with the employee).

chunks.html_content: From 6 April 2024, employers will need to make a decision within 2 months of getting the request.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
From 6 April 2024, employers will need to make a decision within 2 months of getting the request.

chunks.html_content:
Read the Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service (Acas) code of practice on flexible working requests.

The employer should write to the employee with:

  • a statement of the agreed changes
  • a start date for flexible working

They should also change the employee’s contract to include the new terms and conditions.

This should be done as soon as possible but no later than 28 days after the request was approved.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
Agreeing the application
Read the Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service (Acas) code of practice on flexible working requests.
The employer should write to the employee with:

  a statement of the agreed changes
  a start date for flexible working

They should also change the employee’s contract to include the new terms and conditions.
This should be done as soon as possible but no later than 28 days after the request was approved.

chunks.html_content:
The employer must tell the employee that they’ve rejected the application.

Employers can reject an application for any of the following reasons:

  • extra costs that will damage the business
  • the work cannot be reorganised among other staff
  • people cannot be recruited to do the work
  • flexible working will affect quality and performance
  • the business will not be able to meet customer demand
  • there’s a lack of work to do during the proposed working times
  • the business is planning changes to the workforce
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
Rejecting an application
Reasons for rejecting
The employer must tell the employee that they’ve rejected the application.
Employers can reject an application for any of the following reasons:

  extra costs that will damage the business
  the work cannot be reorganised among other staff
  people cannot be recruited to do the work
  flexible working will affect quality and performance
  the business will not be able to meet customer demand
  there’s a lack of work to do during the proposed working times
  the business is planning changes to the workforce

chunks.html_content:
Employees no longer have a statutory right to an appeal.

But offering an appeals process helps to demonstrate that the employer is handling requests in a ‘reasonable manner’.

The employee must follow the company’s procedures for appealing.

The employee or employer should follow the company’s procedures for solving a workplace dispute if a rejected application causes problems.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
How to appeal
Employees no longer have a statutory right to an appeal.
But offering an appeals process helps to demonstrate that the employer is handling requests in a ‘reasonable manner’.
The employee must follow the company’s procedures for appealing.
The employee or employer should follow the company’s procedures for solving a workplace dispute if a rejected application causes problems.

chunks.html_content:
Employees can complain to an employment tribunal if the employer:

  • did not handle the request in a ‘reasonable manner’
  • wrongly treated the employee’s application as withdrawn
  • dismissed or treated an employee poorly because of their flexible working request, for example refused a promotion or pay rise
  • rejected an application based on incorrect facts
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
Going to an employment tribunal
Employees can complain to an employment tribunal if the employer:

  did not handle the request in a ‘reasonable manner’

  wrongly treated the employee’s application as withdrawn
  dismissed or treated an employee poorly because of their flexible working request, for example refused a promotion or pay rise
  rejected an application based on incorrect facts

chunks.html_content: Employees cannot complain to a tribunal just because their flexible working request was rejected.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
Going to an employment tribunal
Employees cannot complain to a tribunal just because their flexible working request was rejected.

chunks.html_content:
An employee should complain to the tribunal within 3 months of:

  • hearing their employer’s decision
  • hearing their request was treated as withdrawn
  • the date the employer should have responded to their request (but failed to do so)
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
Going to an employment tribunal
An employee should complain to the tribunal within 3 months of:

  hearing their employer’s decision
  hearing their request was treated as withdrawn

  the date the employer should have responded to their request (but failed to do so)

chunks.html_content: If an employer or employee is unsure of their rights, they should get legal advice.
chunks.plain_content:
Flexible working
Going to an employment tribunal
If an employer or employee is unsure of their rights, they should get legal advice.
